Description: A quality control tool for high throughput raw sequence data.
Features: It generates quality reports for NGS data and gives pass/fail results for the following checks: Per base sequence quality, Per sequence quality scores, Per base sequence content, Per base GC content, Per sequence GC content, Per base N content, Sequence length distribution, Sequence duplication levels, Overrepresented sequences, Kmer content. It also has a Graphic User Interface.
Strength: It is easy to use; provides visualization in HTML reports; can be used on Illumina, PacBio, 454 reads.
{\"value\" : \"single-end\" , \"text\":: single-ended;  {"value":"paired-end", "text":"Apply to forward and reverse strands separately."}

Description: The FASTX-Toolkit is a collection of command line tools for short-reads FASTA/FASTQ files preprocessing.
Features: The sub-command "fastx_trimmer" can be used to shorten reads (removing barcodes or noise) in FASTQ files. The sub-command "fastqx_clipper" can remove sequencing adapters or linkers.
Strength: Besides "fastx_trimmer" and "fastx_clipper" in this toolkit, there are multiple tools and commands for processing FASTA/FASTQ files. It can also be integrated and used on the web-based bioinformatics platform Galaxy.
Limitation: Last updated in 2010. {"value": "Be ware of the older base quality encoding. ", "link" : "https://wikis.utexas.edu/display/bioiteam/FASTQ+Manipulation+Tools" }

Description: A flexible read trimming tool for Illumina NGS data.
Features: It can trim adapter sequences, remove low-quality reads and bases.
Strength: It is designed as more pair-aware for paired-end data. The authors found trimmomatic to run faster than cutadapt and FASTX-Toolkit.  ({"value":"see Trimmomatic paper","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4103590/"})

Description: Cutadapt finds and removes adapter sequences, primers, poly-A tails and other types of unwanted sequences from high-throughput sequencing reads.
Features: Cutadapt helps with various trimming tasks by finding the adapter or primer sequences in an error-tolerant way. It can also modify and filter reads in various ways. Adapter sequences can contain IUPAC wildcard characters. Also, paired-end reads and even colorspace data are supported. If you want, you can also just demultiplex your input data, without removing adapter sequences at all ({"value":"see manual","link":"https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/cutadapt/stable/cutadapt.pdf"}).
Strength: It supports 454, Illumina and SOLiD (colour space) data. It is used inside another tool called {"value":"Trim Galore","text":"https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_galore/"}, also a quality control tool by the FastQC team.

Description: An ultrafast memory-efficient short read aligner.
Features: It uses Burrows-Wheeler transform to create a permanent, reusable index of the genome.
Strength: It aligns short DNA sequences (reads) to the human genome at a rate of over 25 million 35-bp reads per hour. Bowtie indexes the genome with a Burrows-Wheeler index to keep its memory footprint small: typically about 2.2 GB for the human genome (2.9 GB for paired-end; {"value":"see Bowtie page", "link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/index.shtml"}). For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and/or more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"link","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Limitation: It does not support gapped alignments; there is an upper limit on read length (1024 bp).
Format_input: FASTQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: Bowtie 2 is an ultrafast and memory-efficient tool for aligning sequencing reads to long reference sequences.
Features: Bowtie2 first extracts "seed" substrings in reads, aligns seeds in an ungapped way, and then performs extension in a gapped way.
Strength: It is used by the ATAC-seq pipeline package {"value": "esATAC", "link": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29522192"}, and the ATAC-seq tutorial from {"value": "here", "link": "https://informatics.fas.harvard.edu/atac-seq-guidelines.html"}. Bowtie 2 supports gapped, local, and paired-end alignment modes. It indexes the genome with an FM Index to keep its memory footprint small: for the human genome, its memory footprint is typically around 3.2 GB. For reads longer than about 50 bp, Bowtie 2 is generally faster, more sensitive, and uses less memory than Bowtie 1. It is particularly good at aligning reads of about 50 up to 100s or 1,000s of characters, and good at aligning to relatively long (i.e. mammalian) genomes.  {"value":"see Bowtie2 page","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/index.shtml"}. It is used by {"value": "ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline", "link": "https://www.encodeproject.org/atac-seq/"}
Limitation: For relatively short reads (e.g. less than 50 bp) Bowtie 1 is sometimes faster and more sensitive than Bowtie 2. {"value":"see this","link":"http://bowtie-bio.sourceforge.net/bowtie2/faq.shtml"}
Format_input: FASTQ, QSEQ, FASTA, Raw sequence per line
Format_output: Bowtie output (one alignment per line), SAM/BAM

Description: BWA is a software package for mapping low-divergent sequences against a large reference genome.
Features: BWA uses a Burrows-Wheeler transform to create an index of the genome. It consists of three algorithms: BWA-backtrack, BWA-SW and BWA-MEM. The first algorithm is designed for Illumina sequence reads up to 100bp, while the other two are for longer sequences ranged from 70bp to 1Mbp. {"value":"link","link":"http://bio-bwa.sourceforge.net/bwa.shtml"}
Strength: BWA allows indels in alignment. BWA is used by {"value":"ENCODE DNase-seq pipeline", "link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/dnase_pipeline"} and {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}.

Description: SAMtools: Utilities for the Sequence Alignment Map (SAM) format.
Features: SAMtools has multiple commands for processing SAM/BAM files. The sub-command "SAMtools-flagstat" can be used to print statistics for SAM/BAM files using the {"value":"FLAG field","link":"https://samtools.github.io/hts-specs/SAMv1.pdf"}.

Description: ATAC-seq post-alignment quality control
Features: "ATACseqQC package not only includes most of the commonly adopted QA metrics such as fragment size distribution, {"value": "mitochondrial read fraction", "text": "It is a known issue that ATAC-seq datasets can contain lots of mitochondrial reads that need to be removed. "}, duplication rate, and aggregated read distribution along proximal promoters, but also provides new functionalities such as gene-centric view of signal distribution, library complexity evaluation and sequencing depth analysis." (see {"value": "the package paper", "link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29490630"})

Description: Picard is a set of command line tools for manipulating high-throughput sequencing (HTS) data and formats such as SAM/BAM/CRAM and VCF.
Features: It can summarize mapping statistics such as insert size, mapping score summary, and quality score summary. In particular, the subcommand Picard-MarkDuplicates can be used to remove duplicates.
Limitation: MarkDuplicates uses coordinate information but not read sequence information.

Description: ATAC-seq post-alignment quality control; contains functions for duplication removal from bam files.
Features: "ATACseqQC package not only includes most of the commonly adopted QA metrics such as fragment size distribution, mitochondrial read fraction, duplication rate, and aggregated read distribution along proximal promoters, but also provides new functionalities such as gene-centric view of signal distribution, library complexity evaluation and sequencing depth analysis." (see {"value": "the package paper", "link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29490630"})

Description: An R package for analysis of ChIP-seq and other functional sequencing data.
Features: It accounts for the offset in forward-strand and reverse-strand reads to improve resolution, compares enrichment in signal to background or control experiments, and can also estimate whether the available number of reads is sufficient to achieve saturation, meaning that additional reads would not allow identification of additional peaks ({"value":"see ENCODE resources","link":"https://genome.ucsc.edu/encode/encodeTools.html" }).
Strength: It is used in {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}, for transcription factor peak calling.
Format_input: SAM/BAM, Bowtie format, MAQ format, Arachne format, tagAlign format

Description: Hotspot calls peaks based on a z-score which denotes the enrichment of sequence tags using a null model based on binomial distribution.
Features: The software requires two passes of calls to hotspot wherin peak calling, thresholding using FDR and random data generation are performed. The algorithm works for regions of varying sizes.
Strength: Hotspot has been shown to work for both broad and very short regions. It is used in {"value":"ENCODE DNase-seq pipeline","link":"https://www.encodeproject.org/pipelines/ENCPL654QMU/"}, for peak calling of DNase-seq data.
Limitation: There are lot of scripts and dependencies for the software. However, they are all documented.

Description: Originally developed particularly for DNase-seq data, F-Seq summarizes the data over genomic loci.
Features: F-Seq offers fragment length estimation, enforces strandedness, corrects for copy number and uses a background model that takes into account repeat sequences in the DNA.
Strength: It is used by the ATAC-seq analysis pipeline package It is used by the ATAC-seq pipeline package {"value": "esATAC", "link": "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29522192"}. F-Seq runs relatively faster than most other peak callers as benchmarked by {"value":"Koohy et al., (2014) PLoS One","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24810143"}. F-Seq also does not require control and mappability data.

Description: Software for motif discovery and next-gen sequencing analysis (Homer)
Features: It has 7 basic operations: factor, histone, super (super enhancer ), groseq, tss, dnase, mC(DNA methylation). It assumes the local density of tags in the data follows a Poisson distribution. Input of control data is highly recommended.
Strength: Homer suite in general has a good tutorial to follow. It can also be used on DNase-seq, GRO-seq, CAGE, DNA methylation data.

Description: ROC-AUC maximizing detection filter (DFilter)
Features: It needs positive training sets that can be estimated from the dataset. Based on the positive sets, it constructs filters to detect signal above the noise which is assumed Gaussian distribution.
Strength: It can also be used on histone and TF ChIP-seq, DNase-seq and FAIRE-seq data.

Description: Model based analysis of ChIP-seq (MACS). Popular for ChIP-seq peak calling but has been used for DNase-seq data as well.
Features: It identifies genome-wide profiles of ChIP-seq or DNase-seq peaks and also models shift size of tags; uses the read strand information with a local Poission model.
Strength: MACS can be run in two modes: narrow mode and broad mode. It is used in {"value":"ENCODE ChIP-seq pipeline","link":"https://github.com/ENCODE-DCC/chip-seq-pipeline"}, {"value": "ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline", "link": "https://www.encodeproject.org/atac-seq/"}, and {"value":"Cistrome", "link": "http://cistrome.org/"}.

Description: ZINBA identifies genomic regions enriched in short reads, calling both broad and narrow modes of enrichment across a range of signal-to-noise ratios.
Features: ZINBA models and accounts for factors that co-vary with background or experimental signal, such as G/C content, copy number variation and mappability scores.
Limitation: Consumes more memory and significantly longer runtime compared to other peak calling software  (benchmarked by  {"value":"Koohy et al., (2014) PLoS One","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24810143"}).

Description: An Easy-to-use Systematic pipeline for ATACseq data analysis.
Features: The packages uses F-seq as the peak caller. Besides, "it covers raw sequencing reads preprocessing (FASTQ files), reads alignment (Rbowtie2), aligned reads file operations (SAM, BAM, and BED files), peak calling (F-seq), genome annotations (Motif, GO, SNP analysis) and quality control report." (see link)
Strength: It organizes a complete analysis pipeline.
Limitation: Consumes more memory and significantly longer runtime compared to other peak calling software  (benchmarked by  {"value":"Koohy et al., (2014) PLoS One","link":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24810143"}).

Description: MEME-ChIP: motif analysis of large DNA datasets
Features: It can perform motif discovery, motif enrichment analysis, motif visualization, binding affinity analysis, and motif identification.
Strength: It has a web interface as well as a command line version.
Limitation: For the online version, the sequence file uploaded cannot exceed 50MB. There is limitation on sequence length.

Description: Software for motif discovery and next-gen sequencing analysis (Homer)
Features: Homer contains a novel motif discovery algorithm, comparing two sets of sequences.
Strength: Homer suite in general has a good tutorial to follow.
Limitation: For the online version, the sequence file uploaded cannot exceed 50MB. There is limitation on sequence length.

Description: RSAT peak-motifs: motif analysis in full-size ChIP-seq datasets
Features: It discovers motifs in peaks sequences and compares with databases.
Strength: It has a web interface as well as a command line version; has no limitation on sequence size or number of peaks; can link to Galaxy.

Description: Python package for calling nucleosomes using ATAC-seq data.
Features: The original paper analyzed ATAC-seq data for nucleosome positioning in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Bowtie2 and MACS2 are used in the pacakge.
Strength: Besides python, also has a R package {"value": "NucleoATACR", "link":"https://github.com/GreenleafLab/NucleoATACR/"}
